title: Stories of the Border Marches
author: Lang, John
snippet: What was the end of Hall of Girsonfield no one has chronicled; it is nothard to imagine the purgatory of his latter years.

title: Stories of the Border Marches
author: Lang, John
snippet: The appointed night came, and erethey started in the uncertain light of a misty moon the keeper ofRedesdale supped at Girsonfield.

title: Stories of the Border Marches
author: Lang, John
snippet: Andso, having opened the door of his heart for the messengers of Satan tocome in, Hall of Girsonfield had not long to wait for his tenants.

title: Stories of the Border Marches
author: Lang, John
snippet: Now it must have seemed to Hall of Girsonfield, the head of the chief ofthe northern clans, a very clear error in judgment for any of the powersthat existed to pass him over and appoint as keeper of Redesdale hisfriend and neighbour, Percival Reed.

title: Stories of the Border Marches
author: Lang, John
snippet: Only a few stones of it now remain, and the new housestands on a much more exposed situation; but when Hall was its occupant,Girsonfield stood on a plot of rich green sward on the east side of theOtter.

title: Stories of the Border Marches
author: Lang, John
snippet: The head of the Hall clan livedat Girsonfield, a little to the north of Otterburn, a farmhouse whichhad belonged to the proprietors of Otterburn Castle since the time ofQueen Elizabeth.
